{80.9125, -0.0510865},      {81.0777, -0.0564664}, {81.2429, -0.05117}, {81.4081, -0.0249809},      {81.5733, -0.00204501}, {81.7385, -0.0035259}, {81.9037,      -0.00623434}, {82.0689, -0.0128054}}}      When I plot these data with _Mathematica_ , I get the following figure: > ![Overview](http://i.stack.imgur.com/9voBl.jpg) By the way, this is a physical, non-local, spin valve signal at a given temperature. What I need is a method to find the two switching fields (actually 4 if negative values are also considered). At present, I doing the following: By hand, I make two linear fits, one for the area where the signal is constant at about $-3$ mOhm, one for the area where the signal is decreasing from $0$ mOhm to $-3$ mOhm. For all temperatures, the first area is nearly the same. In the second area, where is this strong decrease of the signal, I have to fit the line by hand. For this example it would be: > >     {{35.3187, 0.779363}, {35.4839, -1.12199}, {35.6491, -2.55552}, >      {35.8143, -2.94135}, {35.9795, -3.09798}} >   From these two lines, I get the intersection point which is what I am interessted in. This method takes me about 10 min for each intersection point because I have to do it by hand, which is OK for one data set. For the 240 data sets that I have this would take a relativly long time, so I'm looking for a way to automate it. The final result looks like this : > ![final result](http://i.stack.imgur.com/fJ9rw.jpg) What I find especially difficult is getting _Mathematica_ to find the correct values for the second line, because I usually have just 3 or 4 measured points for such lines. I hope someone will respond with some nice ideas how this can be done automatically.
